outputs.literature: The supine patient has the face turned towards the contralateral shoulder (Fig. 1). The pillow underneath the head is carefully positioned to provide adequate space for the probe and the needle without compromising asepsis. The operator sits on the same side of the block with the ultrasound machine placed on the opposite side of the patient trolley, so that the eye, needle, probe, and screen are all aligned. A sterile high-frequency (10–13 MHz) probe is used to scan the neck transversely between the level of cricoid cartilage and supraclavicular fossa until an optimal view of the hypoechoic round images of C5 and 6 nerve roots or upper trunk is obtained (Fig. 2). A 50-mm block needle is then carefully inserted either parallel (in-plane from lateral to medial) or perpendicular (out-of-plane) to the probe. We recommend an in-plane approach for single-shot nerve blocks (Video 1, Fig. 2), but an out-of-plane approach (cranial to caudal) may be useful for siting a catheter between the scalene muscles for continuous postoperative infusion analgesia. The plexus is enclosed within an interscalene fascial sheath and the needle is advanced carefully, lateral to medial, through scalenus medius muscle, with the needle shaft continuously visualized, until the fascial sheath overlying the plexus, is contacted. There remains some debate as to whether this fascia should be routinely pierced or the injection performed at this point, reducing chances of needle to nerve contact. We tend to puncture the fascia to obtain spread medial and lateral to the plexus, but confined within the interscalene fascial sheath, to attempt to minimize phrenic nerve blockade. If performed in this way, care must be taken to continually visualize the needle tip and aim between, rather than targeting nerve roots, to avoid nerve contact or intraneural injection. Studies have determined the minimum effective local anaesthetic volume for postoperative shoulder analgesia to be as little as 0.9 ml with ultrasound when compared with 5.4 ml with nerve stimulation.3 We routinely use 8–10 ml of ropivacaine 2 mg ml−1 when using the block for postoperative analgesia in combination with GA, but will use larger volumes (15–20 ml) of a higher concentration to guarantee an effective anaesthetic block for awake surgery.
outputs.clinic_output:
**Initial Probe Placement**

1. Transducer: Use a high-frequency linear probe (10-15 MHz) for optimal resolution of superficial structures in the interscalene region.
2. Patient Position: Position the patient supine with the head turned 30-45 degrees contralaterally and the shoulder slightly depressed to facilitate probe placement and visualization of target structures.
3. Probe Placement: Place the probe transversely above the clavicle, centered between the medial and lateral borders of the neck, with a slight caudad tilt to align with the interscalene groove.

**Landmark Identification**

1. SCM (Sternocleidomastoid muscle): Hyperechoic, thick, and dark line laterally, serving as a landmark for the lateral border of the interscalene space.
2. MSA (Medial Supracleidomastoid muscle, not typically used in interscalene blocks; here, assume reference means scalene medius): Hyperechoic, thick, and dark line medially, indicating the medial border of the interscalene space. Note: In clinical practice, scalene anterior and medius muscles are more relevant landmarks; however, given the image description, MSA here refers to scalene medius for context.
3. TPM (Transverse Pectoral muscle, not typically visualized in interscalene blocks; assume reference means omohyoid muscle here): Thin, hyperechoic line anteriorly, running from the sternum toward the clavicle, serving as a superficial reference point. Note: In clinical practice, the omohyoid muscle is more relevant anteriorly in this region; however, given the image description, TPM here refers to omohyoid muscle for context.
4. Brachial Plexus Elements: Identify the hypoechoic, rounded, or oval-shaped nerve structures (C5-C7 roots) between the SCM and MSA muscles, using the "string of pearls" mnemonic to confirm their appearance.

**Tips for Optimizing Image**

1. Adjust probe depth: Optimize depth between 2-4 cm to visualize the target nerves and surrounding muscles.
2. Adjust gain: Optimize gain to enhance contrast between hypoechoic nerves and hyperechoic muscles.
3. Probe pressure: Apply gentle probe pressure to avoid compressing target structures and vessels.
4. Tilt adjustment: Fine-tune the probe tilt to align with the interscalene groove and optimize visualization of the brachial plexus roots.
5. Doppler: Use Doppler mode to confirm the absence of vessels in the needle path.

**Needle Path & Safety Tips**

1. Needle approach: Use an in-plane approach from lateral to medial, visualizing the entire needle shaft as it advances toward the target.
2. Target location: Insert the needle between the SCM and MSA muscles, aiming for the center of the interscalene space, where the C5-C7 roots are clustered.
3. Structures to avoid: Avoid the anterior scalene muscle, vessels (subclavian artery and vein), and the phrenic nerve, which lies anteriorly and laterally to the interscalene space.
4. Injection technique: Inject 1-2 mL aliquots of local anesthetic under real-time ultrasound visualization, ensuring spread around the target nerves and avoiding intraneural injection. Monitor for signs of intravascular injection and avoid injecting into vessels.

outputs.literature: Patient is supine or sitting up slightly with the head to the contralateral side. Transducer is placed 2-3cm superior to the midpoint of the clavicle, or slightly superior to the external jugular vein if it can be appreciated. Two techniques can be used to identify the cords for the interscalene block. 1) The carotid artery can be identified deep to the sternocleidomastoid, then the probe can be slid posteriorly until a stack of cords is seen in between the anterior and middle scalenes. 2) Identify the subclavian artery in the supraclavicular fossa and trace the brachial plexus up into the interscalene space.Once this view is obtained, an in-plane approach should be used. The needle should be advanced from lateral to medial towards the vertical stack of cords between the anterior and middle scalene muscles (interscalene space).
outputs.clinic_output:
**Initial Probe Placement**

1. Transducer: Use a high-frequency linear probe (10-15 MHz).
2. Patient position: Place the patient supine with head turned 30-45 degrees contralaterally (to the side opposite the block) and shoulder slightly depressed to facilitate exposure of the interscalene region.
3. Probe placement: Position the probe transversely above the clavicle, centered over the interscalene space. Apply a slight caudad (inferior) tilt to optimize visualization of the targeted nerves.

**Landmark Identification**

1. **Cervical Canal (dashed orange circle)**: Recognize the cervical canal as a hypoechoic (darker) tubular structure housing the spinal cord. This landmark helps in identifying the proximity to critical neural elements and aids in avoiding them during the procedure.
2. **Interscalene Region**: Confirm the space between the middle and anterior scalene muscles (MS and AS), which will appear as distinct, hyperechoic (brighter) bands. This region contains the targeted brachial plexus elements (C5-C7 roots).
3. **Middle Scalene Muscle (MS)**: Identify the middle scalene muscle as a hyperechoic, elliptical structure on the lateral side (right in this image).
4. **Anterior Scalene Muscle (AS)**: Recognize the anterior scalene muscle as another hyperechoic, elliptical structure adjacent to the middle scalene muscle, on the medial side (left in this image).

**Tips for Optimizing Image**

1. Depth: Adjust the depth setting to 2-4 cm to encompass the targeted nerves and surrounding musculature.
2. Gain: Optimize gain settings to improve contrast between hyperechoic and hypoechoic structures without creating excessive artifact or noise.
3. Probe pressure: Apply gentle pressure to minimize compression artifact and maintain a clear view of the targeted nerves and vessels.
4. Tilt: Maintain a slight caudad tilt to keep the targeted nerves centered in the image and improve visualization.

**Needle Path & Safety Tips**

1. Needle approach: Use an in-plane technique, advancing the needle laterally to medially (from right to left in this image).
2. Target location: Aim for the space between the middle and anterior scalene muscles, near the level of the C6 nerve root (or targeted level based on surgical requirements).
3. Structures to avoid: Be cautious of the cervical canal (to avoid spinal cord injury), the subclavian artery (to avoid vascular injury), and the phrenic nerve (to avoid diaphragmatic paresis).
4. Injection technique: Inject 1-2 mL aliquots under real-time ultrasound visualization, ensuring spread within the interscalene space and proximity to targeted nerve roots. Monitor for signs of intraneural injection (e.g., sudden nerve swelling or high injection pressure).

outputs.literature: Ideally, the patient should be placed supine with the head of the bed elevated to approximately 30 degrees. A towel or bump can be placed under the affected shoulder to rotate the thorax so that the needle can be advanced in at a flat angle (this allows for better needle visualization). With the patient’s head turned away from the affected side, place a high-frequency linear transducer on the neck lateral to the cricoid cartilage. For novice sonographers who are unfamiliar with the regional anatomy of the brachial plexus, we recommend first to identify the carotid artery and internal jugular vein. Slide the transducer lateral until the sternocleidomastoid muscle can be seen lying superficially to the anterior scalene muscle. By sliding the transducer just laterally, the interscalene groove can be identified between the anterior and middle scalene by the characteristic traffic light appearance of the C5-C7 nerve roots lying vertically between the muscle bodies. If possible, we recommend placing color Doppler over the hypoechoic circular nerve roots to ensure that they are not vasculature. After identifying the C5-C7 nerve roots and other relevant anatomical structures, a small skin wheal should be placed approximately 1 cm lateral to the probe. Using the skin wheel as the point of entry, a 21 to 23 gauge 1 ½ inch block needle should be advanced under ultrasound guidance using an in-plane technique. The needle tip is then advanced just above the middle scalene muscle. The goal is to place anesthetic just under the prevertebral fascia that overlays the superficial border of the middle scalene muscle. Ideally, the anechoic fluid will spread down the interscalene groove in between the brachial plexus and the middle scalene muscle, but this may not always be possible. When the needle tip is appropriately positioned, a local anesthetic will spread along the fascial plane, separating the nerve roots from the middle scalene. (fig 11 and 12) Often, small needle tip adjustments are needed to achieve anesthetic spread along the fascial plane.
outputs.clinic_output:
**Initial Probe Placement**

1. Transducer: Use a high-frequency linear probe (10-15 MHz) for optimal resolution in superficial structures.
2. Patient position: Place the patient supine with head turned 30-45 degrees contralaterally and shoulder mildly depressed to facilitate access to interscalene region.
3. Probe placement: Position the probe transversely just above the clavicle, with a slight caudad tilt to align with the orientation of the brachial plexus elements in this region.

**Landmark Identification**

1. SCM (sternocleidomastoid muscle): Hyperechoic, thick muscle mass medial in the image.
2. AS (anterior scalene muscle): Hyperechoic muscle anterior to BP (brachial plexus elements) in this interscalene view.
3. MS (middle scalene muscle): Hyperechoic muscle positioned laterally in the image.
4. BP (brachial plexus elements): Anechoic or hypoechoic neural structures indicated by an arrow in the image, nestled between AS and MS muscles.

**Tips for Optimizing Image**

1. Depth: Adjust depth to 2-4 cm to focus on superficial structures in the interscalene region.
2. Gain: Optimize gain to improve contrast between muscles and neural elements.
3. Probe pressure: Apply gentle pressure to avoid compression artifact on neural structures.
4. Tilt: Fine-tune caudad tilt for optimal alignment with neural elements.
5. Doppler: Use Doppler sparingly to identify nearby vessels but avoid interference with neural visualization.

**Needle Path & Safety Tips**

1. Approach: Use an in-plane approach from lateral to medial to improve needle visibility.
2. Target: Aim for the BP elements between AS and MS muscles.
3. Structures to avoid: Take care to avoid pleura (inferiorly), major vessels (color Doppler guidance), and phrenic nerve (located anteriorly and medially).
4. Injection technique: Inject 1-2 mL aliquots under real-time ultrasound guidance to ensure proper distribution within the BP elements and avoid pressure buildup or neural compression.

Note: This clinical advice is specific to the interscalene brachial plexus block based on the provided image description and follows regional anesthesia practice parameters. Use clinical judgment and adapt guidance for individual patient variations or specific clinical scenarios.

outputs.literature: With the patient in the proper position, the skin is disinfected and the transducer is positioned in the transverse plane to identify the carotid artery. Once the artery has been identified, the transducer is moved slightly laterally across the neck. The goal is to identify the anterior and middle scalene muscles and the elements of the brachial plexus that is located between them. It is recommended to use the color Doppler to identify vascular structures and avoid them. The needle is then inserted in-plane toward the brachial plexus, typically in a lateral-to-medial direction (Figure 6), although a medial-to-lateral needle orientation can also be used if there is no room for the former. The needle should always be aimed in between the roots instead of directly at them in order to minimize the risk of accidental nerve injury. As the needle passes through the prevertebral fascia, a certain “pop” is often appreciated. When nerve stimulation is used (0.5 mA, 0.1 msec), the entrance of the needle in the interscalene groove is often associated with a motor response of the shoulder, arm, or forearm as another confirmation of proper needle placement. After careful aspiration to rule out intravascular needle placement, 1–2 mL of local anesthetic is injected to verify proper needle placement (Figure 7-A). It is necessary to ensure that high resistance to injection is absent to decrease the risk of intrafascicular injection. Injection of several milliliters of local anesthetic often displaces the brachial plexus away from the needle. Additional advancement of the needle 1–2 mm toward the brachial plexus may be beneficial to ensure the proper spread of the local anesthetic. When injection of the local anesthetic does not appear to result in a spread around the brachial plexus, additional needle repositioning and injections may be necessary.
outputs.clinic_output:
**Initial Probe Placement**

1. Transducer: High-frequency linear probe, 10-15 MHz.
2. Patient Position: Supine, head turned 30-45 degrees contralaterally (to the side opposite the block), shoulder slightly depressed.
3. Probe Placement: Transversely above the clavicle, with a slight caudad (inferior) tilt.

**Landmark Identification**

1. Anterior Scalene Muscle (AS, left side in image): Hyperechoic, rectangular in cross-section, located medial to the brachial plexus.
2. Lower Accessory (or Middle Scalene, LA, left side in image): Also hyperechoic, smaller and more lateral compared to AS.
3. Posterior Scalene Muscle (BP, right side in image, marked with yellow arrows): Hyperechoic, smaller and more posterior compared to AS; note that this label seems misplaced as it's described on the right side while our target is the left interscalene space, but for this example, we'll consider it as illustrating the posterior scalene's general position.
4. Brachial Plexus: Anechoic, clustered nerve structures between AS and LA; "string of pearls" appearance.
5. Needle Tip: Depicted with a blue arrow, centrally located within the interscalene space.

**Tips for Optimizing Image**

1. Depth: Adjust to 2-4 cm to improve visualization of brachial plexus.
2. Gain: Fine-tune to emphasize hyperechoic muscles and anechoic nerves.
3. Probe Pressure: Apply gentle pressure to avoid compression artifacts.
4. Tilt: Make slight adjustments to improve alignment with nerve structures.
5. Doppler: Not necessary for this specific block, but consider using color Doppler to rule out nearby vessels.

**Needle Path & Safety Tips**

1. Needle Approach: In-plane, lateral-to-medial.
2. Target Location: Between AS and LA, within the interscalene space.
3. Structures to Avoid: Pleura, subclavian artery/vein, phrenic nerve.
4. Injection Technique: Inject 1-2 mL aliquots under real-time ultrasound guidance; monitor spread of local anesthetic.

Remember that this specific image description shows a slightly unusual labeling (right posterior scalene on the left side), but our focus remains on the interscalene space between AS and LA, with adjustments based on actual patient anatomy during the procedure.
